TITLE:
   Chief Complaint: 82 yo with a hx of DM, CAD s/p CABG [**2152**] redo [**10/2171**]
   (LIMA-LAD, SVG-OM, SVG-Diag), CHF (EF 51%), and EtOH abuse, admitted to
   OSH for shortness of breath and chest pain and transferred to the [**Hospital1 19**]
   for cardiac catheterization that was aborted [**1-29**] delirium and agitation
   on [**1-22**] until [**1-25**]: Promus LIMA to LAD, on RHC.
   24 Hour Events:
   [**2-5**]
   -Patient conversant, knows he is in [**Hospital 23**] Hospital in [**2182-1-28**].
   Patient angry about restraints and attention from RNs.  Mental status
   markedly improved.
   [**2-4**]
   - Refusing POs after olanzapine ; given lower dose (22 u ) NPH and no
   humalog for bld gluc 121 this AM
   - started standing low dose seroquel at 7pm, per [**Female First Name (un) **]; will increase
   dose if needed
   - re-consulted Geriatrics for delirium --> seroquel QHS, and consider
   starting Neurontin low dose tomorrow night (pt was on neurontin at home
   previously, stopped end of [**Month (only) **] for some reason)
   - bradycardia down to 30s w junctional rhythm, then HR back to 80s
   - febrile, blood and urine cultures, stat CXR
   - transferred back to CCU
   - ABG shows pH 7.43 paCO2 55, paO2 75 despite tachypnea
   - diuresing well; also given a dose of IV acetazolamide in setting of
   metabolic alkalosis; clinically respiratory status looks improved,
   breathing ~28/min (rather than >40)
   - ABG 4:30pm showed improved pCO2
   - given nighttime olanzapine ~9pm (had started becoming awake/agitated
   again around 8am but not too agitated)-- (didnt use seroquel as planned
   b/c he didnt seem like he could swallow reliably); gave him the
   antipsychotic to help him rest --> appeared to work for a while, but
   nursing thought it was just because he tired himself out...
   - 3am pt became more agitated kicking around, trying to get out of bed
   to go to work; nurse didnt feel zyprexa would work anyway; couldnt get
   an ekg to check QT either b/c pt so agitated; put him on leg restraints
   (only while nurse was in room w him)
   - 5:30am screaming out for help constantly ; gave 2.5mg olanzapine 6am;
   will need ekg when calm
   Allergies:
   No Known Drug Allergies
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Other ICU medications:
   Other medications:
   Changes to medical and family history:
   Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below
   Review of systems:

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:12.9/29.4/1.1, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:38/3/0.11, ALT / AST:29/42, Alk Phos / T Bili:75/0.9,
   Amylase / Lipase:/10, Lactic Acid:0.9 mmol/L, Ca++:9.3 mg/dL, Mg++:1.8
   mg/dL, PO4:2.2 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   82 yo with hx of CABG, DM, etoh abuse, transferred for cardiac
   catheterization after ICU admission for respiratory failure during
   which time he had an elevated Troponin and was intubated for hypoxic
   respiratory failure and DTs.
   .
   #. NSTEMI/CAD: Patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization are
   concerning for unstable angina and enzymes at OSH were suggestive of
   NSTEMI in the setting of Troponin elevation. However, no EKGs are
   available from the OSH. Serum troponin on admission to [**Hospital1 19**] was 0.04.
   Cardiac catheterization demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 &
   LIMA-LAD grafts, but patient agitation during procedure prevented
   completion of cardiac catheterization. Currently, patient has a new
   stent in the SVG-OM1 that is partially expanded. He is awaiting
   catheterization on [**1-24**] for evaluation and treatment of the LIMA
   occlusion. Currently, he is chest pain free, but refusing EKG.
   - ASA 325mg daily
   - Atorvastatin 80mg daily
   - Plavix 75mg daily
   - Metoprolol Tartrate 25mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Heparin gtt
   - No Integrillin given current Troponin
   .
   #. Acute on chronic systolic CHF: CHF with EF51% as assessed by nuclear
   imaging at OSH in mid-[**Month (only) 25**]. Patient with persistent fluid overload
   on admission, but he was not pre-hydrated in anticipation of cardiac
   catheterization. On transfer, patient demonstrates mild respiratory
   distress and O2 requirement, limited clinical exam suggests fluid
   overload.
   - Lasix 40mg IV x 1, repeat PRN
   - O2 by NC
   - Metoprolol Tartrate 25mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Lisinopril 2.5mg daily
   .
   # Agitation/Mental status changes: Patient's cardiac catheterization
   aborted [**1-29**] agitation that was refractory to significant doses of
   Haldol. Per patient's wife and [**Name (NI) 755**] Hospital records, patient has
   been confused and agitated since his hospitalization at [**Location (un) 755**]. He
   pulled out his Foley prior to transfer to the [**Hospital1 19**] and his wife
   reports that he was paranoid at [**Location (un) 755**], insisting that the FBI was out
   to get him. At home, however, his wife states that he is not confused,
   but does exhibit short-term memory impairments. As patient has been
   attempting to get out of bed, pulling at lines, and is not fully
   oriented despite repeated verbal reorientation, his primary process
   appears to be agitation with some minor component of dementia/delirium.
   Patient also takes Ativan PO PRN at home, so he may have some component
   of benzodiazepine withdrawal.
   - Psych consult, recommending 0.5 to 1mg q4H:PRN agitation
   - Will try to avoid Haldol/Zyprexa as it will further prolong QT
   interval
   - Frequent reorientation
   - Minimize lines & tubes
   - Preserve sleep wake cycles
   - OOB for meals
   .
   #. Rhythm: Patient in and out of AF in the CCU, but no report of h/o of
   AF. He has also been persistently tachycardic, despite having a regular
   rhythm on admission. This may be agitation paired with diuresis, but
   will continue to monitor closely.
   - On telemetry
   - Metoprolol Tartrate 25mg PO BID
   .
   #. DM: Will continue NPH & insulin sliding scale from OSH.
   - NPH 20u [**Hospital1 7**] & Humalog sliding scale
   - Gabapentin 600mg PO qHS
   .
   #. EtOH abuse: Patient with h/o DT's with EtOH withdrawal, most
   recently at [**Location (un) 755**] prior to hospital transfer. Drinks a pint of
   whiskey a day at home, but his last drink was prior to admission to
   [**Location (un) 755**] on [**1-7**]. He was maintained on a CIWA scale during that
   hospitalization, but also takes Ativan 1mg PO BID:PRN at home so he
   could have some degree of benzodiazepine withdrawal.
   - IV Ativan 0.5mg-1mg q4H:PRN
   - SW consult
   .
   #. HLD: Continue Atorvastatin 80mg daily.
   .
   #. HTN:
   -Continue Lisinopril 2.5mg daily
   -Continue Metoprolol Tartrate 25mg PO BID
   .
   #. GERD:
   - Ranitidine 150mg PO BID
   .
   #. Anxiety/Depression:
   - Per psychiatry, appears to be a distant diagnosis.
   - Continue to observe
   .
   #. Hx of TIA: Short-term left hand and leg weakness, now resolved. No
   focal neurologic deficits on admission.
   .
   #. FEN: Cardiac/diabetic, MVI
   .
   #. Access: PIV, right subclavian line (will plan to d/c when patient
   cooperative)
   .
   #. PPx: Heparin gtt
   .
   #. Communication: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 2064**] [**Known lastname 12865**] ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 12866**]
   .
   #. Code: FULL
   .
   #. Dispo: pending repeat cardiac catheterization
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   22 Gauge - [**2182-2-4**] 12:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old man with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), chronic heart failure (CHF) with an ejection fraction (EF) of 51%, and ethanol (EtOH) abuse. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for shortness of breath and chest pain and transferred to the hospital for cardiac catheterization, which was aborted due to agitation and delirium. The patient has been experiencing agitation, confusion, and aggression, which has been managed with olanzapine and seroquel. He has also been experiencing tachycardia, hypertension, and respiratory distress.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Myocardial infarction (MI) or non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) due to occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts.
	* Cardiac arrhythmias, such as atrial fibrillation (AF) or ventricular tachycardia (VT), due to the patient's tachycardic state.
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to respiratory failure and fluid overload.
	* Pneumonia or aspiration due to the patient's tachypnea and respiratory distress.
3. Neurological Complications:
	* Seizures or status epilepticus due to the patient's history of EtOH withdrawal and benzodiazepine withdrawal.
	* Delirium or agitation due to the patient's underlying medical conditions, EtOH withdrawal, and benzodiazepine withdrawal.
4. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to the patient's history of EtOH abuse and gastrointestinal ulcers.
5. Infections:
	* Bacteremia or sepsis due to the patient's indwelling lines and catheters.
	* Urinary tract infection (UTI) or pneumonia due to the patient's urinary catheter and respiratory distress.
6. Hematological Complications:
	* Thrombocytopenia or bleeding due to the patient's history of EtOH abuse and liver disease.
7. Endocrine Complications:
	* Hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia due to the patient's diabetes mellitus and the use of insulin and oral hypoglycemic agents.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and blood pressure closely.
2. Administer anticoagulation therapy to prevent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).
3. Continue to manage the patient's agitation and delirium with antipsychotic medications and behavioral interventions.
4. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and provide supplemental oxygen as needed.
5. Consider consulting a pulmonologist or critical care specialist to assist with the patient's respiratory management.
6. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels closely and adjust insulin and oral hypoglycemic agents as needed.
7. Consider consulting a nephrologist or critical care specialist to assist with the patient's fluid management and electrolyte balance.

   cardiac catheterization s/p DES to LIMA-LAD, c/b intubation for
   hypoxemic respiratory failure and continued agitation.
   24 Hour Events:
   - started low dose seroquel at 7pm per [**Female First Name (un) **]
   - re-consulted Geriatrics for delirium --> seroquel QHS, and consider
   starting Neurontin low dose tomorrow night (pt was on neurontin at home
   previously, stopped end of [**Month (only) **] for some reason)
   - bradycardia down to 30s w junctional rhythm, then HR back to 80s -
   possible vagal, ?aspiration
   - febrile, blood and urine cultures, stat CXR
   - transferred back to CCU
   - ABG shows pH 7.43 paCO2 55, paO2 75 despite tachypnea
   - diuresing well; also given a dose of IV acetazolamide in setting of
   metabolic alkalosis; clinically respiratory status looks improved,
   breathing ~28/min (rather than >40)
   - given nighttime olanzapine ~9pm (had started becoming awake/agitated
   again around 8am but not too agitated)-- (didnt use seroquel as planned
   b/c he didnt seem like he could swallow reliably); gave him the
   antipsychotic to help him rest --> appeared to work for a while, but
   nursing thought it was just because he tired himself out.
   - 3am pt became more agitated kicking around, trying to get out of bed
   to go to work; nurse didnt feel zyprexa would work anyway; couldnt get
   an ekg to check QT either b/c pt so agitated; put him on leg restraints

Chief Complaint: 82M with hx of CABG, DM, etoh abuse, transferred for
   cardiac catheterization s/p DES to LIMA-LAD, c/b intubation for
   hypoxemic respiratory failure and continued agitation.
   24 Hour Events:
   - started low dose seroquel at 7pm per [**Female First Name (un) **]
   - re-consulted Geriatrics for delirium --> seroquel QHS, and consider
   starting Neurontin low dose tomorrow night (pt was on neurontin at home
   previously, stopped end of [**Month (only) **] for some reason)
   - bradycardia down to 30s w junctional rhythm, then HR back to 80s -
   possible vagal, ?aspiration
   - febrile, blood and urine cultures, stat CXR
   - transferred back to CCU
   - ABG shows pH 7.43 paCO2 55, paO2 75 despite tachypnea
   - diuresing well; also given a dose of IV acetazolamide in setting of
   metabolic alkalosis; clinically respiratory status looks improved,
   breathing ~28/min (rather than >40)
   - given nighttime olanzapine ~9pm (had started becoming awake/agitated
   again around 8am but not too agitated)-- (didnt use seroquel as planned
   b/c he didnt seem like he could swallow reliably); gave him the
   antipsychotic to help him rest --> appeared to work for a while, but
   nursing thought it was just because he tired himself out.
   - 3am pt became more agitated kicking around, trying to get out of bed
   to go to work; nurse didnt feel zyprexa would work anyway; couldnt get
   an ekg to check QT either b/c pt so agitated; put him on leg restraints
   (only while nurse was in room w him)

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), and ethanol (etoh) abuse. He was transferred to the ICU for cardiac catheterization after experiencing hypoxemic respiratory failure and agitation. The patient's cardiac catheterization revealed occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts, and he received a stent to SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.8°C, heart rate of 97 bpm, and blood pressure of 121/67 mmHg. He is intubated and receiving oxygen therapy. The patient's respiratory status has improved, with a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute.

The patient has been experiencing agitation and mental status changes, which have been managed with chemical restraints and sedation. He has also been experiencing seizures, which have been controlled with anticonvulsant medication.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, suggesting myocardial infarction (MI). His cardiac enzymes are elevated, and he has been prescribed anticoagulation therapy.

The patient's medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, metoprolol, and lisinopril. He is also receiving insulin and sliding scale insulin for his diabetes.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac catheterization revealed occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure can worsen, leading to respiratory arrest.
3. Seizures: The patient's seizures can recur, requiring further anticonvulsant therapy.
4. Infection: The patient's catheterization and intubation can increase his risk of infection.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anticoagulation therapy and medication can increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Renal failure: The patient's diabetes and cardiac condition can increase his risk of renal failure.
7. Stroke: The patient's cardiac condition and catheterization can increase his risk of stroke.

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to monitor his vital signs closely and adjust his medications and treatment plan as needed. Additionally, the patient's mental status changes and agitation require close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has been experiencing hypoxemic respiratory failure, which can lead to further respiratory complications such as pneumonia, respiratory acidosis, or even respiratory arrest.
2. Sepsis: The patient has been febrile, and blood and urine cultures are pending. If the cultures are positive, it may indicate sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and even death.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of CABG and NSTEMI/CAD, which increases the risk of cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or even cardiac arrest.
4. Delirium: The patient has been experiencing agitation and mental status changes, which can be a sign of delirium. This can lead to increased agitation, aggression, or even withdrawal from care.
5. Infection: The patient has multiple lines and tubes, which increases the risk of infection. The presence of multiple broken wires and small amount of pleural effusion on the left also suggests a potential infection.
6. Neurological complications: The patient has multiple new lesions in his brain likely secondary to cath procedures with emboli. This can lead to neurological complications such as stroke, seizures, or even brain death.
7. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient has been given IV acetazolamide to treat metabolic alkalosis, which can lead to further complications such as hypokalemia or hypochloremia.
8. Fluid overload: The patient has been diuresed, but the presence of fluid overload can lead to further complications such as pulmonary edema, heart failure, or even respiratory failure.
9. Withdrawal syndrome: The patient has a history of EtOH abuse, and withdrawal syndrome can occur if the patient is not monitored closely.
10. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of GERD, which can lead to further complications such as aspiration, esophagitis, or even gastrointestinal bleeding.

In summary, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, including respiratory failure, sepsis, cardiac complications, delirium, infection, neurological complications, metabolic alkalosis, fluid overload, withdrawal syndrome, and gastrointestinal complications. Close monitoring and management are essential to prevent or treat these complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of CABG, DM, and etoh abuse, who was transferred to the ICU for cardiac catheterization after developing hypoxemic respiratory failure and continued agitation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on nasal cannula oxygen with a SpO2 of 94%. His ABG shows pH 7.43, paCO2 55, and paO2 75. He has been diuresed well and is currently on IV acetazolamide for metabolic alkalosis.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has a history of NSTEMI/CAD and has undergone cardiac catheterization with DES to LIMA-LAD. His cardiac enzymes are elevated, and he has mild cardiomegaly on CXR.
* Neurological status: The patient is agitated and has been requiring restraints and chemical restraints. He has multiple new lesions in his brain likely secondary to cath procedures with emboli.
* Medications: The patient is taking multiple medications, including aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, metoprolol, and insulin sliding scale.
* Laboratory results: The patient's lab results show elevated troponin, CK, and CKMB levels, as well as mild liver enzyme elevation.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and he may require further interventions to improve his oxygenation.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's history of NSTEMI/CAD and elevated cardiac enzymes may indicate ongoing cardiac damage, which could lead to further complications.
* Neurological complications: The patient's agitated state and multiple new lesions in his brain may indicate ongoing neurological damage, which could lead to further complications such as seizures or brain herniation.
* Infection: The patient's history of catheterization and presence of central venous lines may increase his risk of developing an infection.
* Bleeding: The patient's history of anticoagulation therapy and presence of central venous lines may increase his risk of bleeding.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the following plan should be considered:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and provide oxygen therapy as needed.
* Continue to manage the patient's cardiac condition with medications and further cardiac catheterization if necessary.
* Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and provide sedation as needed to manage his agitation.
* Continue to monitor the patient for signs of infection and bleeding.
* Consider a psych consult to further evaluate and manage the patient's agitation and mental status changes.
* Consider a transfer to a floor bed when the patient's condition stabilizes.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), ethanol abuse, and chronic systolic heart failure (CHF) with an estimated ejection fraction (EF) of 30-35%. The patient was transferred to the hospital for cardiac catheterization and was found to have occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts.

The patient's condition has been complicated by:

1. Altered mental status/delirium: The patient has been agitated since admission, with multiple new lesions in his brain likely secondary to catheter procedures with emboli. He has required restraints and chemical restraints intermittently.
2. Acute on chronic systolic CHF: The patient appeared fluid overloaded and had hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation. He has been diuresed, and Lasix was discontinued yesterday.
3. NSTEMI/CAD: The patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization were concerning for unstable angina, and enzymes at the outside hospital were suggestive of NSTEMI in the setting of Troponin elevation.
4. DM: The patient has diabetes mellitus and is being treated with NPH and insulin sliding scale from the outside hospital.
5. EtOH abuse: The patient has a history of ethanol abuse and is being monitored for withdrawal.
6. HLD: The patient is being treated with Atorvastatin 80mg daily for hyperlipidemia.
7. HTN: The patient has hypertension and is being treated with Lisinopril 2.5mg daily and Metoprolol Tartrate 12.5mg PO BID.
8. GERD: The patient has gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and is being treated with Ranitidine 150mg PO BID.
9. Anxiety/Depression: The patient's mental status is stable, and he is being observed.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Further decline in mental status/delirium: The patient's agitation and delirium could worsen, requiring increased sedation and potentially leading to respiratory compromise.
2. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid status is a concern, and further fluid overload could exacerbate his CHF and lead to respiratory failure.
3. NSTEMI/CAD progression: The patient's NSTEMI/CAD could progress, leading to further cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrest or arrhythmias.
4. DM complications: The patient's diabetes could worsen, leading to hyperglycemia, ketoacidosis, or other complications.
5. EtOH withdrawal: The patient's ethanol withdrawal could lead to seizures, delirium, or other complications.
6. HLD progression: The patient's hyperlipidemia could worsen, leading to increased cardiovascular risk.
7. HTN complications: The patient's hypertension could worsen, leading to increased cardiovascular risk and potential complications, such as stroke or cardiac arrest.
8. GERD complications: The patient's GERD could worsen, leading to respiratory complications, such as aspiration pneumonia.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

1. Serotonin receptor antagonist (Seroquel) for agitation
2. Antipsychotic medication (Neurontin) for agitation
3. Diuretics (Lasix and Torsemide) for fluid overload
4. Antiplatelet agents (Aspirin and Plavix) for NSTEMI/CAD
5. Statins (Atorvastatin) for hyperlipidemia
6. Beta blockers (Metoprolol) for hypertension and CHF
7. Insulin and NPH for DM
8. Ranitidine for GERD
9. Low-dose ACEI for hypertension
10. Heparin for DVT prophylaxis

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is pending further evaluation and treatment.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), and ethanol abuse, who was transferred to the ICU for cardiac catheterization and management of hypoxemic respiratory failure and agitation.

The patient's mental status has been altered, with episodes of hypoactive and hyperactive delirium. He has been agitated since admission, requiring restraints and chemical restraints to prevent injury to himself and others. The patient has multiple new lesions in his brain, likely secondary to catheter procedures with emboli.

The patient's cardiovascular status is complex, with a history of acute on chronic systolic heart failure (CHF) with an ejection fraction of 30-35%. He has been diuresed and has had episodes of hypotension, requiring decreases in his diuretic and vasodilator medications. The patient's blood pressure may correlate with his urine output and mental status.

The patient has also been diagnosed with non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and coronary artery disease (CAD), with occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts. He has undergone cardiac catheterization and stenting of these grafts.

The patient's laboratory results show abnormalities in his electrolyte levels, including hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hyperphosphatemia. His liver enzymes are also elevated, with an alkaline phosphatase level of 75 units/L and an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 42 units/L.

Potential medical complications that may arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Worsening of delirium and agitation, potentially leading to injury or self-harm.
2. Hypotension and decreased urine output, potentially leading to acute kidney injury.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias, potentially leading to cardiac arrest or sudden death.
4. Respiratory failure, potentially leading to mechanical ventilation and prolonged ICU stay.
5. Infection, potentially leading to sepsis and multi-organ failure.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding, potentially leading to hypovolemic shock and organ failure.
7. Stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA), potentially leading to long-term neurological deficits.

Based on the patient's complex medical conditions, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of his vital signs, laboratory results, and medication regimen to prevent and address potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of CABG, DM, and ethanol abuse, admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and elevated Troponin. He underwent cardiac catheterization and was intubated for DTs. The patient has been experiencing agitation, delirium, and sun-downing, which is being managed with quetiapine and frequent reorientation. He also has cellulitis of the left ankle and is being treated with cephalexin. The patient has a history of NSTEMI/CAD and is being managed with ASA, atorvastatin, plavix, and metoprolol. He is also being treated for DM with NPH and insulin sliding scale, and has a history of ethanol abuse.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure has been unstable, and he has had episodes of hypotension. This could be due to the medications he is taking, including metoprolol and torsemide.
2. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's history of NSTEMI/CAD and his current medications make him at risk for cardiac arrest.
3. Sepsis: The patient has cellulitis of the left ankle, which could progress to sepsis if not treated promptly.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure could worsen if not managed properly.
5. Delirium: The patient's delirium could worsen if not managed properly, and could lead to increased agitation and aggression.
6. Infection: The patient's cellulitis and history of ethanol abuse make him at risk for infection.
7. Renal Failure: The patient's history of DM and his current medications could put him at risk for renal failure.
8. Hemorrhage: The patient's history of NSTEMI/CAD and his current medications make him at risk for hemorrhage.
9. Arrhythmias: The patient's history of AF and his current medications make him at risk for arrhythmias.
10. Pulmonary Embolism: The patient's history of VTE and his current medications make him at risk for pulmonary embolism.

Recommendations:

1. Monitor the patient's blood pressure closely and adjust his medications as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's delirium with quetiapine and frequent reorientation.
3. Continue to treat the patient's cellulitis with cephalexin and monitor for signs of sepsis.
4. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his oxygen therapy as needed.
5. Consider adding antibiotics to the patient's regimen to prevent infection.
6. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust his medications as needed.
7. Monitor the patient's hemoglobin and hematocrit levels closely and adjust his medications as needed.
8. Consider adding a stress ulcer prophylaxis to the patient's regimen.
9. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels closely and adjust his medications as needed.
10. Consider adding a prophylactic anticoagulant to the patient's regimen to prevent VTE.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following information:

**Current Condition:**

The patient is an 82-year-old man with a history of CABG, DM, and ethanol abuse, who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and elevated Troponin. He underwent cardiac catheterization and stenting of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD for 95% stenoses. Currently, he is experiencing intermittent respiratory distress, delirium, and agitation.

**Vital Signs:**

* Temperature: 36.7°C (98°F)
* Heart Rate: 89 bpm
* Blood Pressure: 104/57 mmHg
* Respiratory Rate: 23 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 97%
* Weight: 96.6 kg (admission: 104.6 kg)

**Lab Results:**

* WBC: 6.2-8.7 K/uL
* Hct: 29.9-33.8%
* Plt: 161-275 K/uL
* Cr: 1.0-1.3 mg/dL
* TCO2: 33-40 mmHg
* Glucose: 125-166 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 12.9/29.4/1.1, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 38/3/0.11, ALT/AST: 29/42, Alk Phos/T Bili: 75/0.9, Amylase/Lipase: 10, Lactic Acid: 0.9 mmol/L, Ca++: 9.3 mg/dL, Mg++: 1.9 mg/dL, PO4: 2.2 mg/dL

**Medical Complications:**

* Acute on chronic systolic CHF
* Persistent pulmonary edema following NSTEMI and PCI
* Cellulitis of L ankle
* NSTEMI/CAD
* Rhythm: Patient in and out of AF
* DM: Controlled on glucose in mid 100s
* EtOH abuse: s/p DTs at OSH
* HLD: Continue Atorvastatin 80mg daily
* Hypotensive episodes
* Anxiety/Depression: Per psychiatry, appears to be a distant diagnosis
* Hx of TIA: Short-term left hand and leg weakness, now resolved
* FEN: Cardiac/diabetic, MVI

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Worsening of CHF
* Development of sepsis or septic shock
* Increased risk of bleeding due to anticoagulation therapy
* Increased risk of arrhythmias due to electrolyte imbalances
* Development of renal failure due to hypotension or CHF
* Increased risk of respiratory failure due to persistent pulmonary edema

**Plan:**

* Continue Torsemide 20mg daily, hold PM dose if BP instability
* O2 by NC
* Metoprolol Tartrate 12.5mg TID
* Quetiapine Fumarate 12.5mg PO/NG Q 6PM, increase to 25mg QD
* Add Haldol PRN per psychiatrist
* Monitor QT, fine yesterday
* Frequent reorientation
* Minimize lines and tubes
* Preserve sleep-wake cycles
* OOB for meals, PT consult
* Repeat CXray

**Recommendations:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and lab results closely
* Adjust medications as needed to manage CHF, hypertension, and DM
* Consider repeating cardiac catheterization to assess coronary artery disease
* Monitor for signs of sepsis or septic shock
* Consider adjusting anticoagulation therapy to reduce risk of bleeding
* Monitor for signs of arrhythmias or electrolyte imbalances
* Consider repeating CXray to assess for signs of respiratory failure

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old man with a history of CABG, DM, and etoh abuse, admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and elevated Troponin after cardiac catheterization. He was intubated for DTs and had a NSTEMI/CAD with OM DES. He has been experiencing delirium/sun-downing, agitation, and mental status changes, and has a history of chronic systolic CHF with EF51%. He has also been experiencing tachycardia and has had intermittent Afib on telemetry.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* NSTEMI/CAD with OM DES: The patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization are concerning for unstable angina, and enzymes at OSH were suggestive of NSTEMI in the setting of Troponin elevation. S/P OM DES.
	* Chronic systolic CHF: The patient has a history of CHF with EF51% as assessed by nuclear imaging at OSH, and persistent pulmonary edema following NSTEMI and PCI.
	* Tachycardia: The patient has been persistently tachycardic, despite having a regular rhythm on admission, which may be agitation paired with diuresis.
2. Respiratory complications:
	* Respiratory failure: The patient was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and was intubated for DTs.
	* Pneumonia: The patient has a history of chronic respiratory disease and has been experiencing respiratory symptoms, which may increase the risk of developing pneumonia.
3. Neurological complications:
	* Delirium/sun-downing: The patient has been experiencing delirium/sun-downing, agitation, and mental status changes, which may be related to his underlying medical conditions or medications.
	* TIA: The patient has a history of TIA, which may increase the risk of developing further neurological complications.
4. Infection complications:
	* UTI: The patient has a history of etoh abuse and has been experiencing urinary symptoms, which may increase the risk of developing UTI.
	* Sepsis: The patient has been experiencing fever and chills, which may be related to an underlying infection.
5. Gastrointestinal complications:
	* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of chronic gastrointestinal disease and has been experiencing gastrointestinal symptoms, which may increase the risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding.
	* Pancreatitis: The patient has been experiencing abdominal pain and has a history of chronic pancreatitis, which may increase the risk of developing pancreatitis.

Overall, the patient is at risk for a range of medical complications, including cardiac, respiratory, neurological, infection, and gastrointestinal complications. Close monitoring and management of his underlying medical conditions and medications will be necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

   .

   .

   .
   #. Anxiety/Depression:
   - Per psychiatry, appears to be a distant diagnosis.

   .
   #. Hx of TIA: Short-term left hand and leg weakness, now resolved. No
   focal neurologic deficits
   .

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

* The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), and ethanol abuse. He was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and elevated troponin levels.
* The patient underwent cardiac catheterization and percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stenting of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD for 95% stenoses.
* The patient has been experiencing agitation, delirium, and sun-downing, which has been managed with sedation and reorientation.
* The patient has been diagnosed with non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and chronic systolic heart failure (CHF) with an ejection fraction of 51%.
* The patient has been treated with medications such as aspirin, atorvastatin, clopidogrel, metoprolol, and lisinopril.
* The patient has been experiencing intermittent atrial fibrillation (AF) and has been treated with metoprolol.
* The patient has a history of ethanol abuse and has been treated with lorazepam, folate, and thiamine.
* The patient has a history of transient ischemic attack (TIA) and has been treated with aspirin and clopidogrel.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Cardiac complications:
	+ Ventricular arrhythmias
	+ Cardiac tamponade
	+ Heart failure exacerbation
* Respiratory complications:
	+ Pneumonia
	+ Respiratory failure
	+ Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Neurological complications:
	+ Stroke
	+ Seizures
	+ Delirium
* Gastrointestinal complications:
	+ Gastrointestinal bleeding
	+ Pancreatitis
	+ Hepatic failure
* Infection complications:
	+ Sepsis
	+ Meningitis
	+ Pneumonia

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent these potential complications and improve the patient's outcome.

The patient's current condition is marked by:

* Delirium/Sun-Downing, which is a concern for agitation and mental status changes.
* Hypotension, which was treated with a 250cc bolus of NS.
* Diffusely inverted T waves in anterior leads on ECG, which is concerning for potential cardiac complications.
* Respiratory support with O2 delivery via nasal cannula.
* Cardiac rhythm changes, including in and out of AFib, which may be related to agitation and diuresis.
* Chronic venous stasis in the left ankle, which is likely unrelated to the current hospitalization.

The patient's labs show:

* Elevated Troponin, which suggests potential cardiac complications.
* Elevated CK and CKMB, which suggests potential cardiac injury.
* Elevated ALT and AST, which suggests potential liver injury.
* Elevated Lactic Acid, which suggests potential metabolic complications.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Cardiac complications, such as NSTEMI/CAD, acute on chronic systolic CHF, and rhythm disturbances.
* Respiratory complications, such as respiratory failure and pneumonia.
* Neurological complications, such as delirium/Sun-Downing and potential stroke.
* Metabolic complications, such as diabetic ketoacidosis and hyperglycemia.
* Infectious complications, such as UTI and pneumonia.
* Gastrointestinal complications, such as stress ulcer and gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is pending repeat cardiac catheterization.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), ethanol abuse, and a recent cardiac catheterization procedure with deployment of stents to the left internal mammary artery-left anterior descending (LIMA-LAD) graft.

The patient's current condition is complicated by:

1. Altered mental status/delirium: The patient has been experiencing alternating hypoactive and hyperactive delirium, which is likely secondary to his underlying medical conditions and the recent catheterization procedure. He has responded to seroquel for a couple of hours last night and required a dose of haldol.
2. Acute on chronic systolic heart failure (CHF): The patient has CHF with an ejection fraction of 30-35% and has been experiencing fluid overload, hypoxemic respiratory failure, and rales. His blood pressure cannot tolerate further diuresis.
3. Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI)/coronary artery disease (CAD): The patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization were concerning for unstable angina, and his serum troponin level was elevated. Cardiac catheterization demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts.
4. Diabetes mellitus: The patient's DM is being managed with NPH and insulin sliding scale from the outside hospital.
5. Ethanol abuse: The patient is being monitored for withdrawal symptoms.
6. Hyperlipidemia: The patient is being treated with atorvastatin 80mg daily.
7. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is being managed with metoprolol tartrate 12.5mg PO BID and holding ACE inhibitor.
8. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD): The patient is being treated with ranitidine 150mg PO BID.
9. Anxiety/depression: The patient's mental status is stable, and he is being observed.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Worsening of delirium: The patient's altered mental status/delirium can worsen if not managed properly.
2. Fluid overload: The patient's CHF can worsen if he becomes fluid overloaded, leading to respiratory failure and increased risk of mortality.
3. Heart failure exacerbation: The patient's CHF can exacerbate if his blood pressure cannot tolerate further diuresis, leading to increased risk of mortality.
4. Recurrent cardiac events: The patient's NSTEMI/CAD can recur if not managed properly, leading to increased risk of mortality and morbidity.
5. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state can increase his risk of infection, particularly with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).
6. Renal failure: The patient's diabetes and CHF can increase his risk of renal failure, particularly if he becomes fluid overloaded.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's CHF and hypoxemic respiratory failure can worsen if not managed properly, leading to increased risk of mortality.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's GERD and increased risk of bleeding can increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is recommended that he be closely monitored and managed in the ICU with a multidisciplinary team, including cardiology, endocrinology, and geriatrics.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), and ethanol abuse, who was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for cardiac catheterization and management of hypoxemic respiratory failure and agitation. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His mental status is altered, with alternating hypoactive and hyperactive delirium, and he has required restraints and chemical restraints to prevent injury to himself and others.

The patient has a history of acute on chronic systolic heart failure (CHF) with an ejection fraction (EF) of 30-35%. He has been diuresed and is receiving furosemide 20mg daily. His blood pressure has been relatively low, and his urine output and mental status may correlate with blood pressure.

The patient also has a history of non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and coronary artery disease (CAD), with occlusion of the saphenous vein graft (SVG)-om1 and left internal mammary artery (LIMA)-left anterior descending (LAD) grafts. He has undergone percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with drug-eluting stents (DES) to the SVG-om1 and LIMA-LAD grafts.

Potential medical complications:

1. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status and agitation may worsen, leading to increased risk of falls, injury, and poor outcomes.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure may progress, requiring increased ventilatory support or even extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of CHF, NSTEMI, and CAD may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, or even cardiac arrest.
4. Infection: The patient's cellulitis of the left ankle may progress, leading to sepsis or septic shock.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and ethanol abuse may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding, nausea, and vomiting.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's history of ethanol abuse and altered mental status may lead to neurological sequelae, such as seizures or stroke.
7. Fluid overload: The patient's history of CHF and diuresis may lead to fluid overload, requiring increased diuretic therapy or even hemofiltration.
8. Blood pressure instability: The patient's history of hypertension and low blood pressure may lead to blood pressure instability, requiring close monitoring and adjustments to antihypertensive therapy.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent or promptly address potential medical complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome (NSTEMI) after undergoing cardiac catheterization with implantation of two drug-eluting stents (DES) in the left internal mammary artery (LIMA) and left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery. He was also diagnosed with hypoxemic respiratory failure, agitation, and delirium. The patient's mental status has been altered, and he has been agitated since admission. He has multiple new lesions in his brain likely secondary to catheter procedures with emboli.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is ongoing, and he continues to require oxygen therapy. There is a risk of further respiratory deterioration, and close monitoring is necessary.
2. Delirium: The patient's delirium is a significant concern, and it may worsen if not managed properly. The use of sedatives, such as haloperidol, may be necessary to control his agitation.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiac status is unstable, and there is a risk of further cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac tamponade, or cardiac rupture.
4. Neurological Complications: The patient's new lesions in his brain may indicate embolic events, which could lead to further neurological complications, such as stroke or transient ischemic attacks.
5. Infection: The patient's respiratory failure and altered mental status make him more susceptible to infection. Close monitoring for signs of infection, such as fever, tachycardia, or changes in mental status, is necessary.
6. Fluid Overload: The patient's fluid balance is mildly negative, and there is a risk of fluid overload if not managed properly. Close monitoring of his fluid status and electrolytes is necessary.
7. Medication-Related Complications: The patient is taking multiple medications, and there is a risk of medication-related complications, such as hypoglycemia, hypotension, or gastrointestinal bleeding.

Based on the patient's complex medical condition, it is essential to provide close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiac, and neurological status. A multidisciplinary approach, including intensivists, cardiologists, neurologists, and other specialists, may be necessary to ensure optimal care and management of the patient's condition.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), ethanol abuse, and a recent procedure for cardiac catheterization with implantation of drug-eluting stents (DES) in the left internal mammary artery (LIMA) and left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery. He was admitted to the hospital with complaints of angina versus non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and was found to have hypoxemic respiratory failure, agitation, and delirium.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3°C, heart rate of 100 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 106/82 mmHg. He is receiving oxygen therapy and is intubated.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of troponin, creatine kinase (CK), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), consistent with a recent myocardial infarction. His complete blood count (CBC) shows anemia, and his electrolyte panel shows hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia.

The patient's imaging studies show no significant changes in his cardiac silhouette or lungs, but he has small left lateral areas of hypoventilation.

The patient's medical conditions include acute on chronic systolic heart failure, NSTEMI/CAD, DM, ethanol abuse, hypertension, and anxiety/depression. He is receiving treatment for his conditions, including medications for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes, as well as oxygen therapy and intubation.

Potential medical complications that may arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
2. Catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBSIs)
3. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
4. Pulmonary embolism (PE)
5. Respiratory failure
6. Cardiac arrhythmias
7. Hypotension
8. Hypoxemia
9. Hypercapnia
10. Delirium
11. Agitation
12. Disorientation
13. Confusion
14. Aggressive behavior
15. Sleep disturbances
16. Nutritional deficiencies
17. Wound infections
18. Catheter-related complications

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of NSTEMI and delirium. The patient has a history of coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), ethanol abuse, and hypertension.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 78-113 bpm, blood pressure of 126/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 94%. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 18 inspirations per minute and a PaO2 of 29 mmHg.

The patient's neurological status is altered, with delirium and agitation. The patient has been agitated since admission and has multiple new lesions in his brain likely secondary to catheter procedures with emboli. The patient is currently on restraints and has been prescribed Haldol for agitation.

The patient's cardiac status is complicated by acute on chronic systolic congestive heart failure (CHF) with an ejection fraction of 30-35%. The patient has rales and requires oxygen therapy, but cannot tolerate further diuresis due to blood pressure concerns.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating a possible NSTEMI. The patient has also been diagnosed with diabetes and is being managed with insulin and a sliding scale.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but the patient is at risk for respiratory failure due to chronic CHF and hypoxemic respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac status is complicated by acute on chronic CHF, and the patient is at risk for cardiac arrhythmias.
3. Infection: The patient's altered mental status and delirium increase the risk of infection, particularly in the ICU setting.
4. Bleeding: The patient's use of anticoagulant therapy and the patient's risk factors for bleeding increase the risk of bleeding complications.
5. Worsening of CHF: The patient's CHF is acute on chronic, and the patient's condition can worsen if not properly managed.
6. Delirium: The patient's delirium can worsen if not properly managed, and the patient is at risk for falls and other complications.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continuing Haldol for agitation and delirium.
2. Continuing metoprolol tartrate for cardiac management.
3. Continuing torsemide for fluid management.
4. Continuing aspirin, plavix, and atorvastatin for cardiac management.
5. Continuing NPH and insulin sliding scale for diabetes management.
6. Monitoring for signs of infection and bleeding.
7. Continuing to manage the patient's cardiac status and respiratory status.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), ethanol abuse, and a recent cardiac catheterization with stenting (DES) to the left internal mammary artery (LIMA) and left anterior descending (LAD) grafts. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for cardiac catheterization, intubation for hypoxemic respiratory failure, and continued agitation.

The patient's current condition is complicated by:

1. Altered mental status/delirium: The patient has been agitated since admission and is likely delirious due to the catheterization procedures and potential emboli. He is currently on restraints, but Haldol may be more effective in managing his behavior.
2. Acute on chronic systolic heart failure (CHF): The patient has a history of CHF with an ejection fraction of 30-35% and is currently experiencing fluid overload and hypoxemic respiratory failure.
3. Cellulitis: The patient has a left lower extremity rash with an eschar above the lesion, which is currently not red or inflamed but will continue to be treated.
4. NSTEMI/CAD: The patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization were concerning for unstable angina, and his enzymes were suggestive of NSTEMI in the setting of troponin elevation. Cardiac catheterization demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD grafts.
5. DM: The patient will continue NPH and insulin sliding scale from the outside hospital.
6. EtOH abuse: The patient will be monitored for withdrawal symptoms.
7. HLD: The patient will continue atorvastatin 80mg daily.
8. HTN: The patient's blood pressure is being closely monitored, and the ACE inhibitor is being held.
9. GERD: The patient will continue ranitidine 150mg PO BID.
10. Anxiety/Depression: The patient's mental status is stable, and he will continue to be observed.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Increased agitation and aggression due to the patient's delirium.
2. Worsening of cardiac function and fluid overload, potentially leading to cardiogenic shock.
3. Development of sepsis or septic shock due to the cellulitis or other infections.
4. Non-healing of the eschar above the cellulitis lesion, potentially leading to further complications.
5. Progression of the patient's NSTEMI/CAD, potentially leading to myocardial infarction or cardiac arrest.
6. Development of diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperglycemic hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome due to the patient's DM.
7. Withdrawal symptoms from ethanol abuse, potentially leading to seizures or other complications.
8. Increased risk of bleeding due to the patient's anticoagulation therapy.
9. Development of pneumonia or other respiratory infections due to the patient's intubation and mechanical ventilation.

The patient's disposition is pending, but it is recommended that he be placed in a geriatric psychiatric bed if possible.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a complex medical history, including coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), ethanol abuse, and a recent cardiac catheterization with DES placement to LIMA-LAD. He was transferred to the ICU for cardiac catheterization, s/p DES to LIMA-LAD, c/b intubation for hypoxemic respiratory failure and continued agitation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Altered Mental Status/Delirium: Alternating Hypoactive and Hyperactive Delirium, likely secondary to cath procedures with emboli. He has multiple new lesions in his brain.
* Acute on Chronic Systolic CHF: CHF with EF 30-35%. He appeared fluid overloaded and had hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation previously.
* Cellulitis: Left lower extremity rash with eschar above lesion.
* NSTEMI/CAD: Patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization are concerning for unstable angina and enzymes at OSH were suggestive of NSTEMI in the setting of Troponin elevation.
* DM: Will continue NPH & insulin sliding scale from OSH.
* EtOH abuse: Outside window for withdrawal. Monitor.
* HLD: Continue Atorvastatin 80mg daily.
* HTN: Holding ACE Inhibitor and continuing Metoprolol Tartrate 12.5mg PO BID.
* GERD: Ranitidine 150mg PO BID.
* Anxiety/Depression: Difficult to assess in setting of delirium, but may be contributing to complicated mental status picture.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Worsening of delirium and agitation, potentially leading to increased risk of falls, restraints, and respiratory compromise.
* Development of further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock, given the patient's history of NSTEMI/CAD and CHF.
* Progression of cellulitis, potentially leading to sepsis and organ failure.
* Increased risk of bleeding and hematoma formation due to recent cardiac catheterization and DES placement.
* Potential for further respiratory compromise and hypoxemia, given the patient's history of hypoxemic respiratory failure and continued oxygen requirement.
* Risk of infection and sepsis, given the patient's immunocompromised state and presence of multiple lines and tubes.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Increasing seroquel to 100mg qhs and adding 25mg qam.
* Continuing standing haldol.
* Re-consulting psychiatry for possible geriatric placement.
* Continuing 20mg torsemide daily to keep fluid balance even.
* Weaning oxygen as tolerated.
* Continuing Metoprolol tartrate 12.5mg TID.
* Holding low-dose ACE inhibitor.
* Continuing NPH and insulin sliding scale from OSH.
* Monitoring for EtOH withdrawal.
* Continuing Atorvastatin 80mg daily.
* Holding ACE Inhibitor.
* Continuing Ranitidine 150mg PO BID.
* Adjusting insulin sliding scale prn.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Tmax: 36.8°C (98.3°F)
* Tcurrent: 34.8°C (94.6°F)
* HR: 96 (83-107) bpm
* BP: 113/54 (67) mmHg
* RR: 24 (14-25) inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 94%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus Rhythm

The patient's laboratory results are:

* WBC: 8.7-5.2 x 10^9/L
* Hct: 33.8-30.7%
* Plt: 174-166 x 10^9/L
* Cr: 1.2-1.3 mg/dL
* TCO2: 33 mmHg
* Glucose: 136-129 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 12.9/29.4/1.1, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 38/3/0.11, ALT/AST: 29/42, Alk Phos/T Bili: 75/0.9, Amylase/Lipase: /10, Lactic Acid: 0.9 mmol/L, Ca++: 9.3 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.2 mg/dL, PO4: 2.2 mg/dL

The patient's medication list includes:

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting, diabetes, and ethanol abuse, who was transferred to the ICU for cardiac catheterization after being intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure and continued agitation. He has been experiencing altered mental status/delirium, which has been managed with increased doses of seroquel. The patient has multiple new lesions in his brain likely secondary to cath procedures with emboli.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T: 36.8°C, HR: 96 bpm, BP: 113/54 mmHg, RR: 24 breaths/min, SpO2: 94%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Stable
* Fluid balance: Mildly negative
* Respiratory support: Oxygen therapy
* Cardiovascular: Systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border
* Neurologic: Attentive, oriented to person and place
* Laboratory results: WBC: 8.7, Hct: 33.8, Plt: 174, Cr: 1.2, TCO2: 33, Glucose: 136

Potential medical complications:

1. Delirium: The patient's delirium is a significant concern, as it can lead to increased agitation, confusion, and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Sepsis: The patient's cellulitis and possible catheter-related infections may lead to sepsis, which can cause multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of coronary artery disease and recent cardiac catheterization may lead to cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or myocardial infarction.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure may worsen, leading to respiratory failure and potential need for mechanical ventilation.
5. Infection: The patient's multiple lines and tubes may increase the risk of infection, which can lead to sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's poor nutritional status may lead to deficiencies in essential nutrients, which can exacerbate his underlying medical conditions.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of GERD and potential gastrointestinal bleeding may lead to gastrointestinal complications such as nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

Assessment and plan:

1. Continue to manage the patient's delirium with increased doses of seroquel and frequent re-orientation.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and adjust medications as necessary.
3. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure with oxygen therapy and consider weaning him off mechanical ventilation.
4. Monitor the patient's fluid balance and adjust diuresis as necessary to prevent fluid overload.
5. Continue to treat the patient's cellulitis and catheter-related infections with antibiotics and close monitoring.
6. Monitor the patient's nutritional status and provide adequate nutrition to prevent deficiencies.
7. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust medications as necessary to prevent gastrointestinal complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 82-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU for cardiac catheterization following a diagnosis of NSTEMI/CAD. He has a history of CABG, DM, and EtOH abuse. The patient is currently receiving treatment for acute on chronic systolic CHF, cellulitis, and anxiety/depression.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 35.3°C (95.6°F)
* Heart rate: 96 bpm (normal range: 73-98 bpm)

* Respiratory rate: 24 inspirations per minute (normal range: 13-25 inspirations per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 97% (normal range: 95-100%)
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient is receiving prophylactic heparin sodium for DVT and has a normal QTc on telemetry.

The patient's physical examination is significant for:

* Well-nourished and overweight/obese appearance
* Cardiovascular examination: S1 and S2 heart sounds are normal, and there is a harsh systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border
* Peripheral vascular examination: Right radial pulse is not assessed, left radial pulse is not assessed, right DP pulse is diminished, and left DP pulse is diminished
* Respiratory/chest examination: Breath sounds are crackles bibasilar
* Abdominal examination: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present, and no distension or tenderness
* Extremities: Right lower extremity edema is trace, and left lower extremity edema is trace
* Skin examination: Rash with eschar on the left leg, appears more like venous stasis than cellulitis
* Neurologic examination: Responds to verbal stimuli, oriented to person, year, and movement is purposeful, but tone is not assessed.

The patient's laboratory results are significant for:

* White blood cell count: 8.7-6.9-5.5-6.1-5.2 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 33.8-31.7-30.4-31.1-30.7%
* Platelet count: 174-161-158-185-166 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.2-1.3-1.3-1.3-1.2 mg/dL
* Glucose: 136-125-166-98-115 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.9 mmol/L
* Calcium: 9.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.2 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Aspirin 325mg
* Plavix
* Atorvastatin 80mg
* Metoprolol tartrate 12.5mg TID
* Torsemide 20mg daily
* Ranitidine 150mg PO BID
* Seroquel 25mg daily
* NPH 22u and Humalog sliding scale for DM
* Heparin SQ for DVT prophylaxis

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Acute on chronic systolic CHF with fluid overload
* Cellulitis with risk of progression to necrotizing fasciitis
* Anxiety/depression with risk of worsening mental status
* NSTEMI/CAD with risk of recurrent cardiac events
* DM with risk of hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia
* EtOH abuse with risk of withdrawal and delirium
* HLD with risk of worsening lipid profile
* HTN with risk of worsening blood pressure control
* GERD with risk of worsening symptoms
* Anxiety/depression with risk of worsening mental status

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue seroquel 25mg daily for delirium
* Continue torsemide 20mg daily for CHF
* Continue metoprolol tartrate 12.5mg TID for CHF
* Continue ranitidine 150mg PO BID for GERD
* Continue NPH 22u and Humalog sliding scale for DM
* Continue aspirin 325mg, plavix, and atorvastatin 80mg for CAD
* Hold ACE inhibitor for HTN
* Continue heparin SQ for DVT prophylaxis
* Monitor for signs of cellulitis and necrotizing fasciitis
* Monitor for signs of worsening mental status and delirium
* Monitor for signs of hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia
* Monitor for signs of worsening lipid profile and HLD
* Monitor for signs of worsening blood pressure control and HTN
* Monitor for signs of worsening symptoms of GERD

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), ethanol abuse, and cardiac catheterization. He was transferred to the hospital for cardiac catheterization and was found to have occlusion of the SVG-OM1 & LIMA-LAD grafts. He was intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure and continued agitation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T = 35.3°C (95.6°F), HR = 96 bpm, BP = 109/60 mmHg, RR = 24 inspirations per minute, SpO2 = 97%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient is receiving heparin sodium prophylaxis.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 1,330 mL of fluids and has lost 570 mL of fluids, resulting in a negative fluid balance of 180 mL.
* Respiratory support: The patient is receiving oxygen therapy, but the delivery device is not specified.
* Physical examination: The patient is well-nourished and overweight, with normal breath sounds and no signs of respiratory distress. He has diminished peripheral pulses in both lower extremities and a rash on his left leg with eschar.
* Laboratory results: The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, as well as elevated blood urea nitrogen and creatinine levels.

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Altered mental status/delirium: The patient has been agitated since admission and has intermittent hyperactive delirium, mostly at night.
* Acute on chronic systolic CHF: The patient has CHF with an estimated ejection fraction of 30-35% and appears to be fluid overloaded.
* Cellulitis: The patient has a left lower extremity rash with scabs above the lesion.
* NSTEMI/CAD: The patient has symptoms consistent with unstable angina and enzymes suggestive of NSTEMI, with troponin elevation.
* DM: The patient has diabetes mellitus and is receiving NPH and insulin sliding scale.
* EtOH abuse: The patient has a history of ethanol abuse and is being monitored for withdrawal.
* HLD: The patient is receiving atorvastatin 80mg daily.
* HTN: The patient has hypertension and is being treated with metoprolol tartrate 12.5mg PO BID.
* GERD: The patient has gastroesophageal reflux disease and is receiving ranitidine 150mg PO BID.
* Anxiety/depression: The patient's mental status is complicated by delirium, making it difficult to assess his anxiety and depression.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue seroquel 100mg qhs and qam for delirium.
* Check EKG for QTc.
* Continue frequent re-orientation.
* Minimize lines and restraints.
* Correct sleep-wake cycles.
* OOB as much as possible.
* Screen for rehab.
* Continue 20mg torsemide daily to keep the patient even.
* Continue metoprolol tartrate 12.5mg TID as tolerated by BP.
* Continue cephelexin for cellulitis.
* Continue aspirin 325mg, plavix, atorvastatin 80mg, and metoprolol tartrate 12.5mg TID for NSTEMI/CAD.
* Continue NPH and insulin sliding scale for DM.
* Monitor for ethanol withdrawal.
* Continue atorvastatin 80mg daily for HLD.
* Continue metoprolol tartrate 12.5mg PO BID for HTN.
* Continue ranitidine 150mg PO BID for GERD.
* Screen for anxiety and depression.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Further deterioration of cardiac function due to CHF and NSTEMI/CAD.
* Development of respiratory failure due to pulmonary edema or pneumonia.
* Progression of delirium to psychosis or coma.
* Development of sepsis or septic shock due to cellulitis or other infections.
* Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia due to diabetes mellitus.
* Ethanol withdrawal syndrome.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to GERD or stress ulcer.
* Deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism due to immobility and DVT prophylaxis.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of CABG, DM, and ethanol abuse, who was admitted to the ICU for cardiac catheterization and intubation due to hypoxemic respiratory failure and agitation. The patient's current conditions include:

1. NSTEMI/CAD: The patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization were concerning for unstable angina, and enzymes at the outside hospital were suggestive of NSTEMI. Cardiac catheterization demonstrated occlusion of the SVG-OM1 & LIMA-LAD grafts, and the patient was treated with DES to SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD.
2. Acute on chronic systolic CHF: The patient appeared fluid overloaded and had hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation previously. He continues to have rales and O2 requirement, but his blood pressure cannot tolerate further diuresis.
3. Cellulitis: The patient has a left lower extremity rash with scabs above the lesion, which appears to be less inflamed currently, but will continue to be treated.
4. Delirium: The patient has been agitated since the outside hospital and has multiple new lesions in his brain likely secondary to cath procedures with emboli. His delirium has improved, but he still has intermittent hyperactive delirium, mostly at night.
5. DM: The patient will continue NPH and insulin sliding scale from the outside hospital.
6. EtOH abuse: The patient is being monitored for withdrawal, and he likely has some degree of alcoholic dementia or Korsakoff encephalopathy contributing to his delirium picture.
7. HLD: The patient will continue Atorvastatin 80mg daily.
8. HTN: The patient's blood pressure is being managed with Metoprolol Tartrate 12.5mg PO BID, and ACE Inhibitor is being held.
9. GERD: The patient is being treated with Ranitidine 150mg PO BID.
10. Anxiety/Depression: The patient's mental status picture is complicated, and it is difficult to assess his anxiety and depression in the setting of delirium.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's NSTEMI/CAD and CHF can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and increased risk of cardiovascular events.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's chronic respiratory failure and O2 requirement can lead to respiratory distress, pneumonia, and respiratory failure.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's delirium and multiple new lesions in his brain can lead to increased risk of seizures, stroke, and cognitive decline.
4. Infections: The patient's cellulitis and potential bacterial infections can lead to sepsis, organ failure, and increased mortality.
5. Metabolic complications: The patient's DM and CHF can lead to hyperglycemia, acidosis, and electrolyte imbalances.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's GERD and potential gastrointestinal bleeding can lead to aspiration pneumonia, gastrointestinal perforation, and bleeding.
7. Psychiatric complications: The patient's delirium, anxiety, and depression can lead to increased risk of suicide, self-harm, and psychiatric complications.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Continued seroquel dosing to manage delirium
2. Minimizing lines and restraints
3. Correcting sleep-wake cycles
4. Encouraging OOB activities
5. Screening for rehab and VA services
6. Continuing medications for CHF, CAD, DM, and HTN
7. Monitoring for withdrawal symptoms and potential bacterial infections

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as needed to prevent potential complications and improve his overall health outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of NSTEMI and delirium. The patient has a history of CABG, DM, and etoh abuse. He was transferred to the hospital for cardiac catheterization and was found to have occlusion of the SVG-OM1 & LIMA-LAD grafts. The patient was intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure and continued agitation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Tmax 36.4°C, Tcurrent 36.2°C, HR 70 bpm, BP 109/56 mmHg, RR 12 inspirations per minute, SpO2 94%.
* Physical examination: The patient is overweight/obese, with a soft and non-tender abdomen, and right lower extremity edema absent.
* Neurological examination: The patient is attentive, follows simple commands, and responds to verbal stimuli. He is oriented to person, time, and movement, but tone and movement assessment was not performed.
* Lab results: The patient's WBC count is 8.7, Hct is 33.8%, Plt is 174, Cr is 1.2 mg/dL, and TCO2 is 33.

The patient's conditions are as follows:

* Altered Mental Status/Delirium: The patient's delirium has improved, but he still experiences intermittent hyperactive delirium, mostly at night. He has multiple new lesions in his brain likely secondary to cath procedures with emboli.
* Acute on Chronic Systolic CHF: The patient has CHF with an EF of 30-35%. He appeared fluid overloaded and had hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation previously. He continues to have rales and O2 requirement but does not have shortness of breath.
* Cellulitis: The patient has a left lower extremity rash with scabs above the lesion. The rash does not appear to be as inflamed currently, but it will continue to be treated.
* NSTEMI/CAD: The patient's symptoms prior to hospitalization are concerning for unstable angina and enzymes at OSH were suggestive of NSTEMI in the setting of Troponin elevation. He was treated with DES to SVG-OM1 and LIMA-LAD.
* DM: The patient will continue NPH and insulin sliding scale from OSH.
* EtOH abuse: The patient likely has some degree of alcoholic dementia or Korsakoff encephalopathy that is contributing to his overall delirium picture.
* HLD: The patient will continue Atorvastatin 80mg daily.
* HTN: The patient's blood pressure is being held with ACE Inhibitor, and he will continue Metoprolol Tartrate 12.5mg PO BID.
* GERD: The patient will receive milk of magnesia as needed.
* Anxiety/Depression: The patient's mental status is difficult to assess in the setting of delirium, but it may be contributing to his complicated mental status picture.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Pneumonia: The patient is at risk for pneumonia due to his intubation and prolonged hospital stay.
* Sepsis: The patient's cellulitis and potential bacterial colonization of his catheters increase his risk for sepsis.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's NSTEMI and CAD increase his risk for cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
* Respiratory complications: The patient's chronic CHF and hypoxemic respiratory failure increase his risk for respiratory complications, such as respiratory failure and pneumonia.
* Delirium: The patient's delirium can lead to complications such as falls, pressure ulcers, and increased risk of hospital-acquired infections.
* Wound complications: The patient's cellulitis and potential bacterial colonization of his wounds increase his risk for wound complications, such as infection and delayed healing.

* Anxiety and depression: The patient may have anxiety and depression, which may be contributing to his delirium. He may require further treatment for these conditions, such as medications or therapy.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications are noted:

**Summary:**

The patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), and ethanol abuse, who was transferred to the ICU for cardiac catheterization after being intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure and agitation. The patient has been diagnosed with altered mental status/delirium, acute on chronic systolic heart failure (CHF), cellulitis, and NSTEMI/CAD. He is currently being treated with various medications, including sedatives, antihypertensives, and antidiabetic agents.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Delirium:** The patient's delirium may worsen due to the lack of effective treatment, leading to increased agitation, respiratory failure, and potential cardiac complications.
2. **Cardiac Complications:** The patient's CHF may worsen due to the lack of effective diuresis, leading to increased fluid overload, respiratory failure, and potential cardiac arrest.
3. **Infection:** The patient's cellulitis may progress, leading to sepsis, organ failure, and potential death.
4. **Thromboembolic Complications:** The patient's history of NSTEMI/CAD and current use of anticoagulants may increase the risk of thromboembolic complications, such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).
5. **Nutritional Complications:** The patient's nutritional status may deteriorate due to the lack of adequate nutrition, leading to malnutrition, weakness, and potential organ failure.
6. **Glycemic Complications:** The patient's DM may worsen due to the lack of effective glucose control, leading to hyperglycemia, ketoacidosis, and potential organ failure.
7. **Anxiety/Depression:** The patient's anxiety and depression may worsen due to the lack of effective treatment, leading to increased agitation, respiratory failure, and potential cardiac complications.
8. **Renal Complications:** The patient's history of DM and current use of antidiabetic agents may increase the risk of renal complications, such as acute kidney injury (AKI) and chronic kidney disease (CKD).

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's delirium and adjust treatment as needed.
2. Optimize the patient's cardiac status by ensuring effective diuresis and controlling blood pressure.
3. Continue to treat the patient's cellulitis and monitor for signs of sepsis.
4. Monitor the patient's thromboembolic risk factors and adjust anticoagulant therapy as needed.
5. Ensure adequate nutrition and adjust glucose control as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's anxiety and depression and adjust treatment as needed.
7. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust antidiabetic therapy as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 82-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a history of coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), diabetes mellitus (DM), and ethanol abuse. He was transferred for cardiac catheterization after presenting with hypoxemic respiratory failure and agitation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Altered mental status/delirium: Improved from prior, but still has intermittent hyperactive delirium, mostly at night.
* Acute on chronic systolic CHF: Fluid overloaded, with rales but no O2 requirement.
* Cellulitis: Left lower extremity rash with scabs above lesion, treated with a 5-day course of cephelexin.
* NSTEMI/CAD: Chest pain free, with cardiac catheterization demonstrating occlusion of the SVG-OM1 & LIMA-LAD grafts.
* DM: Will continue NPH & insulin sliding scale from OSH.
* EtOH abuse: Outside window for withdrawal, with likely chronic alcohol-induced dementia or Korsakoff encephalopathy contributing to delirium.
* HLD: Continue Atorvastatin 80mg daily.
* HTN: Holding ACE Inhibitor, with continued Metoprolol Tartrate 12.5mg PO BID.
* Anxiety/Depression: Difficult to assess in setting of delirium, but may be contributing to complicated mental status picture.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Worsening of delirium and agitation, potentially leading to increased risk of falls, injury, or even physical harm to the patient or others.
2. Fluid overload, which may lead to pulmonary edema, acute respiratory distress syndrome, or even cardiac failure.
3. Infection, particularly in the left lower extremity, which may lead to sepsis, bacteremia, or abscess formation.
4. NSTEMI/CAD, which may lead to further cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, or cardiac arrest.
5. DM, which may lead to hyperglycemia, ketoacidosis, or even diabetic coma.
6. EtOH withdrawal, which may lead to seizures, delirium tremens, or even withdrawal seizures.
7. HLD, which may lead to increased risk of cardiovascular events, such as myocardial infarction or stroke.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continue seroquel 100mg qam for delirium management.
2. Continue trazodone 50mg for sleep and anxiety management.
3. Minimize lines and restraints.
4. Correct sleep-wake cycles.
5. OOB as much as possible.
6. Screen for Rehab and potentially look for VA services.
7. PT/OT consult.
8. Continue medication regimen as ordered.

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust the plan of care as needed to prevent potential complications and ensure optimal management of his various medical conditions.
